snippet: This week’s death and destruction was amplified by the lack of anti-seismic codes that are too costly, too complicated and too cumbersome to approve....
abstract: Historic architecture, considered cultural asset in Italy, amplified damage from August earthquake as older buildings crumbled; country's rich architectural heritage is costly, as government spends some 3.5 billion euros per year to fix earthquake damage and shore up ancient infrastructure; corruption prevents some anti-seismic efforts from being carried out properly.

byline.original: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

lead_paragraph: This week’s death and destruction was amplified by the lack of anti-seismic codes that are too costly, too complicated and too cumbersome to approve.

headline.main: Quake Exposes Italy’s Challenge to Retrofit Its Architecture
headline.print_headline: An Asset to Italy, Its Architectural Heritage, Turns to Liability in Quakes
